{{use mdy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox video game |title=Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode II |image=[[File:S4E2 Boxart.png|250px]] |caption=Cover art |developer=[[Dimps]]
[[Sonic Team]] |publisher=[[Sega]] |producer=[[Takashi Iizuka (game designer)|Takashi Iizuka]]
Hiroyuki Kawano |director=Makoto Suzuki |programmer=Kōji Okugawa |artist=Hideaki Moriya
[[Yuji Uekawa]]
Satoshi Takemura |designer=Kenji Ayukawa |composer=[[Jun Senoue]] |series=''[[Sonic the Hedgehog (series)|Sonic the Hedgehog]]'' |released={{collapsible list|title=May 15, 2012{{cite web|last=Oliver |first=Tristan |url=http://www.tssznews.com/2012/04/05/new-sonic-4-episode-ii-trailer-debuts/ |title=UPDATE: New Sonic 4: Episode II Trailer Debuts |publisher=Tssznews|date=April 5, 2012|accessdate=April 22, 2012}}|'''Microsoft Windows'''{{vgrelease|WW|May 15, 2012{{cite web|url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/203650/|title=Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode II |publisher=[[Steam (software)|Steam]]|date=May 15, 2012|accessdate=August 30, 2013}}}}'''PlayStation 3'''{{cite web|url=http://ps3.gamespy.com/playstation-3/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-ii/|title=Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode II (PlayStation 3) |publisher=[[GameSpy]]|accessdate=October 18, 2013}}{{vgrelease|NA|May 15, 2012|EU|May 16, 2012}}{{vgrelease|JP|May 16, 2012}}'''Xbox 360'''{{vgrelease|WW|May 16, 2012{{cite web|url=http://xbox360.gamespy.com/xbox-360/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-ii/|title=Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode II (Xbox 360) |publisher=[[GameSpy]]|accessdate=October 18, 2013}}}}'''Android'''{{vgrelease|WW|May 16, 2012{{cite web|url=http://www.androidpolice.com/2012/05/16/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-ii-review-a-really-great-game-if-you-have-a-controller-and-some-patience/|title=Sonic The Hedgehog 4 Episode II Review: A Really Great Game - If You Have A Controller... And Some Patience |publisher=Android Police|date=May 16, 2012|last=Ruddock|first=David|accessdate=October 18, 2013}}}}'''iOS'''{{vgrelease|WW|May 17, 2012{{cite web|url=http://ie.ign.com/games/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-ii/iphone-125729|title=Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode II (iOS) |publisher=[[IGN]]|accessdate=October 18, 2013}}}}'''Ouya'''{{vgrelease|WW|July 3, 2013{{cite web|url=http://www.pocketgamer.co.uk/r/Ouya/Sonic+The+Hedgehog+4%3A+Episode+1/news.asp?c=52204|title=Sonic spin dashes onto Ouya in Sonic The Hedgehog 4: Episodes I and II|publisher=[[Pocket Gamer]]|date=July 9, 2013|last=Usher|first=Anthony|accessdate=October 18, 2013}}}}'''Nvidia Shield'''{{vgrelease|WW|July 31, 2013{{cite web|url=http://blogs.sega.com/2013/07/31/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-ii-thd-pre-loaded-on-nvidia-shield/|title=Sonic The Hedgehog 4: Episode II THD Pre-Loaded on NVIDIA SHIELD|publisher=Sega Blog|date=July 31, 2013|accessdate=August 30, 2013}}}}}} |genre=[[Platform game|Platformer]] |modes=[[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] |platforms=[[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[iOS]], [[Ouya]], [[Shield Portable]], [[Shield Android TV]] }} {{nihongo foot|'''''Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode II'''''|ソニック・ザ・ヘッジホッグ{{ruby|4|フォー}} エピソード{{ruby|II|ツー}}|Sonikku za Hejjihoggu Fō: Episōdo Tsū|lead=yes|group=lower-alpha}} is a {{vgy|2012}} [[episodic video game|episodic]] [[platform game|platform video game]] in the ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog (series)|Sonic the Hedgehog]]'' series, the sequel to ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode I]]''. The game was developed by [[Dimps]], with assistance from [[Sonic Team]],{{cite web|url=http://forums.sega.com/showpost.php?p=5587337&postcount=1|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130104165937/http://forums.sega.com/showpost.php?p=5587337&postcount=1|dead-url=yes|archive-date=January 4, 2013|title=Who's making Sonic 4? Well, since you asked...|publisher=Sega Forums|date=February 24, 2011|accessdate=June 30, 2013}} and published by [[Sega]]. The game was intended to emulate the original ''Sonic the Hedgehog'' games on the [[Sega Genesis]]. ''Episode II'' was released in May 2012 for [[Personal computer|PC]] (via [[Steam (software)|Steam]]), [[PlayStation Network]], [[Xbox Live Arcade]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], and [[iOS]], and in July 2013 for [[Ouya]],{{cite news|last=Williams|first=Mike|title=Sega embracing "disruptive" Ouya with Sonic|url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2013-06-05-sega-embracing-disruptive-ouya-with-sonic|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=June 5, 2013}} and [[Nvidia Shield]] (as a preinstalled app). A version for the [[Windows Phone]] was slated to be released in July 2012,{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-2/videos/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-2-ken-balough-interview-6348001 |title=Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode 2 Ken Balough Interview |publisher=[[GameSpot]]|date=December 29, 2011 |accessdate=March 27, 2012}} but was cancelled. A [[Wii]] version was planned to be released via [[WiiWare]], although it was cancelled due to hardware constraints.{{cite web|url=http://wiiware.nintendolife.com/news/2011/12/sega_confirms_no_wiiware_outing_for_sonic_4_episode_ii |title=SEGA Confirms No WiiWare Outing for Sonic 4: Episode II |last=Newton|first=James|publisher=Wiiware.nintendolife|date=December 30, 2011|accessdate=March 27, 2012}} An additional episode, "Episode Metal", which centers around [[Metal Sonic]], is available for those who purchase both episodes for the same system. In late 2014, the iOS version was removed from the App Store due to firmware incompatibility, but in early 2016, the game was updated to work on the latest firmware and returned to the store. ==Gameplay== [[File:Sonic 4 Episode 2 screenshot.jpg|thumb|left|In-game screenshot, showing both Sonic and Tails]] ''Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode II'' is a [[2D computer graphics|2D]] [[Side-scrolling video game|side-scrolling]] platformer reminiscent of the original ''Sonic'' games for the [[Sega Mega Drive]]/Genesis. It plays very similarly to the previous episode, but with several enhancements. [[Sonic the Hedgehog (character)|Sonic]] is now accompanied by [[Tails (character)|Tails]], either controlled by the computer or a second player via [[Local area network|local]] or [[Multiplayer online game|online]] co-operative play. Unlike the earlier [[16-bit]] games, Tails cannot be played in single-player mode, and likewise Sonic can't be played on his own.{{cite web|url=http://www.sonicstadium.org/2012/02/tails-limited-to-2-player-mode-in-sonic-4-episode-2/ |title=Tails Limited to 2 Player Mode in Sonic 4: Episode 2 |publisher=Sonic Stadium |date=February 23, 2012|accessdate=March 27, 2012}} There are also various combination moves that Sonic and Tails can perform together, such as Tails lifting Sonic up to places he would be unable to reach otherwise, or the two rolling into a ball to perform a fast and powerful spin attack.{{cite web|last=Workman |first=Robert |url=http://www.gamezone.com/products/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-ii/previews/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-2-preview |title=Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode 2 |publisher=GameZone |date=May 18, 2012 |accessdate=May 22, 2012}} Special Stages in ''Episode II'' are accessed the same way as in ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode I|Episode I]]'' (finishing an act with at least 50 rings and then jumping into the Giant Ring that appears at the end of the stage), and are based on the [[half-pipe]] style format introduced in ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog 2 (16-bit)|Sonic the Hedgehog 2]]'', in which the player is required to collect a certain number of rings before the goal in order to obtain a [[Chaos Emerald]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sonicstadium.org/2012/02/xbox-com-releases-first-screenshots-of-sonic-4-episode-2-co-op-play-also-revealed/ |title=Xbox.com Releases First Screenshots of Sonic 4: Episode 2, Co-op Play Also Revealed |publisher=Sonic Stadium |date=February 14, 2012|accessdate=May 27, 2012}} The game also features Red Star Rings, which previously appeared in ''[[Sonic Colors]]'' and ''[[Sonic Generations]]'', with one Red Ring hidden per act.{{cite web|url=http://www.sonicstadium.org/2012/02/sega-europe-releases-more-sonic-4-episode-2-screenshots/ |title=SEGA Europe Releases More Sonic 4: Episode 2 Screenshots |publisher=Sonic Stadium |date=February 5, 2012|accessdate=March 27, 2012}} Cross-compatibility was planned for the Xbox Live Arcade and Windows Phone versions, allowing players to alternate their games by means of [[Cloud storage|Cloud saving]], but the idea was removed because the Windows Phone version was cancelled.{{cite web|url=http://www.gametrailers.com/video/gdc-2012-sonic-the/728043 |title=Sonic The Hedgehog 4: Episode II Video Game, GDC 2012: Features Interview HD|publisher=GameTrailers|date=March 14, 2012|accessdate=March 27, 2012}} Owners of both ''Episode I'' and ''II'' on the same system can unlock free "Episode Metal" content in ''Episode II''. "Episode Metal" explains how [[List of Sonic the Hedgehog video game characters#Metal Sonic|Metal Sonic]] came back to life after being defeated in ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog CD|Sonic CD]]'', and players can play as Metal Sonic through four acts, all of which are reworked from the first act of each Zone in ''Episode I''. ==Plot== Metal Sonic survived his previous defeat in ''Sonic CD'', but was severely damaged, and left on Little Planet when it disappeared at the end of the game. After the events of ''Episode I'', Little Planet returns, and Dr. Eggman locates and repairs Metal Sonic.{{cite web|author=Ishaan |url=http://www.siliconera.com/2011/12/29/tails-returns-as-a-playable-character-in-sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-2/ |title=Tails Returns As A Playable Character In Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode 2 |publisher=Siliconera |date=December 29, 2011|accessdate=March 27, 2012}} Sonic hears that Eggman is back, and reunites with Tails to stop him. Meanwhile, Metal Sonic, after receiving a mysterious power source, searches for the heroes and sees them fly away in the Tornado, following them using Tails' rocket.{{cite web |url=http://www.sonicthehedgehog4.com/us/ |title=Sonic The Hedgehog 4 Official Website |publisher=[[Sega]] |date= |accessdate=March 27, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120403233106/http://www.sonicthehedgehog4.com/us/ |archivedate=April 3, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} It is revealed that Eggman plans to construct a new Death Egg mk.II over Little Planet. As the dwarfed planet heads back into space, Sonic and Tails follow the villains to the Death Egg. Inside, they confront and defeat Metal Sonic. Later, they defeat Eggman at the heart of the base. Sonic and Tails then escape via space pods just before the Death Egg begins to explode. As the credits roll, the duo head back to Earth while the Death Egg shuts down. ==Development== In February 2011, ''Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode II'' was confirmed to be in early development. [[Sega]] Brand Manager Ken Balough stated that "the idea is to introduce new zones with things you haven't seen." He has also hinted that ''Episode II'' may have a larger budget than ''Episode I'', due to the commercial success of ''Episode I''. Balough also stated that many of the ideas in ''Episode II'' were planned while the first episode was still under development.{{cite web|last=Oliver |first=Tristan |url=http://www.tssznews.com/2011/02/25/sonic-4-episode-ii-now-in-early-development-says-ken-balough/ |title=Sonic 4: Episode II Now "In Early Development", Says Ken Balough |publisher=Tssznews|date=February 25, 2011|accessdate=June 21, 2011}} Sega of America Community Manager Aaron Webber also hinted that Tails may appear in ''Episode II''.{{cite web|last=Oliver|first=Tristan|title=Sega Celebrates Hedgehog Day, Hints at Tails in Sonic 4: Episode 2?|url=http://www.tssznews.com/2011/02/03/sega-celebrates-hedgehog-day-hints-at-tails-in-sonic-4-episode-2/|publisher=Tssznews|date=February 3, 2011|accessdate=June 30, 2013}} On August 23, 2011, Sonic Team head [[Takashi Iizuka (game designer)|Takashi Iizuka]] stated that "this year, 2011, is the anniversary, so we're focusing on the celebration title, but moving forward to 2012, Sonic will still be going, so I'd hope to provide Episode 2 then." He also said that Sonic Team "knew about the anniversary year," and that "''Generations'' was planned way in advance." As such, "it was always our plan to release Episode 2 after Generations."{{cite web|author=GeneHF |url=http://www.sonicretro.org/2011/08/sonic-4-episode-2-in-2012-episode-3-unlikely/ |title=Sonic 4: Episode 2 in 2012, Episode 3 Unlikely|publisher=Sonicretro|date= |accessdate=March 27, 2012}} In preparation for ''Episode II''{{'}}s release, Sega re-released ''Sonic the Hedgehog CD'' to digital platforms in late 2011, billing it as a 'prequel' to ''Sonic 4'', as the events of ''Episode II'' would rely heavily on what occurred in ''CD''. On December 29, a teaser trailer for ''Episode II'' was released, and it was revealed that both Metal Sonic and Tails would be returning. It was also revealed that the game would feature an updated graphics and physics engine from ''Episode I''. Platforms confirmed for release were Xbox Live Arcade, PlayStation Network, iOS, Android, Windows Phone and PC.{{cite web|url=http://www.sonicstadium.org/2012/01/sonic-4-episode-2-confirmed-for-pc-download/ |title=Sonic 4: Episode 2 Confirmed For PC Download |publisher=Sonic Stadium |date=January 19, 2012|accessdate=March 27, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5871797/sonic-4-episode-2-is-already-changing-stuff |title=Sonic 4: Episode 2 is Already Changing Stuff |last=Plunkett|first=Luke|publisher=Kotaku|date=December 29, 2011|accessdate=March 27, 2012}} It was also confirmed that no [[WiiWare]] version of ''Episode II'' would be released, with it being highly assumed that the [[Wii]] version was cancelled due to hardware constraints. On April 21, 2012, an early beta version of ''Episode II'' was accidentally made available to people who pre-ordered the game on [[Steam (software)|Steam]]. However, Sega quickly removed it.{{cite web|last=Sanchez |first=David |url=http://www.gamezone.com/products/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-ii/news/sonic-4-episode-ii-was-leaked-on-steam |title=Sonic 4: Episode II was leaked on Steamews |publisher=GameZone |date=May 18, 2012 |accessdate=May 22, 2012}} In March 2012, Iizuka has said that Sega was not planning on releasing any further episodes of ''Sonic 4''.{{cite web|last=Batchelor |first=James |url=http://www.mcvuk.com/news/read/future-sonic-4-episodes-canned/092748 |title=Future Sonic 4 episodes canned |publisher=Mcvuk|date=March 23, 2012|accessdate=March 27, 2012}} In 2015, it was revealed that ''Sonic 4'' was originally conceptualized as a trilogy, but it was considered a duology because plans to develop ''Episode III'' were abandoned for undisclosed reasons.{{cite web | url=http://www.tssznews.com/2015/01/04/ken-balough-sonic-4-episode-iii-is-never-happening | title=Ken Balough: "Sonic 4 Episode III Is Never Happening" | publisher=Tssznews.com | date=January 4, 2015 | accessdate=January 7, 2015}} ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | MC = (iOS) 66/100{{cite web |url=https://www.metacritic.com/game/ios/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-ii |title=Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode II for iPhone/iPad Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=July 4, 2013}}
(PS3) 63/100{{cite web |url=https://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-3/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-ii |title=Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode II for PlayStation 3 Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=May 23, 2012}}
(X360) 61/100{{cite web |url=https://www.metacritic.com/game/xbox-360/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-ii |title=Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode II for Xbox 360 Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=May 23, 2012}}
(PC) 54/100{{cite web |url=https://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-ii |title=Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode II for PC Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=October 29, 2018}} | 1UP = B+{{cite web|url=http://www.1up.com/reviews/sonic-hedgehog-4-episode-ii|title=Sonic the Hedgehog 4 Episode II Review: Blue Renewed|last=Barnholt|first=Ray|publisher=[[1UP.com]]|date=May 14, 2012|accessdate=November 19, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69MozWOZR?url=http://www.1up.com/reviews/sonic-hedgehog-4-episode-ii|archivedate=July 23, 2012|df=mdy-all}} | EGM = 6.5/10{{cite web|url=http://www.egmnow.com/articles/reviews/egm-review-sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-ii/ |title=EGM Review: Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode II |last=Carsillo|first=Ray|publisher=EGMNOW |date=May 15, 2012|accessdate=May 22, 2012}} | GameRev = {{Rating|2|5}}{{cite web|author=KevinS|url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/review/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-2|title=Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode II Review |publisher=[[Game Revolution]]|date=May 29, 2012|accessdate=August 26, 2013}} | GSpot = 6/10{{cite web|last=Neigher|first=Eric|url=http://uk.gamespot.com/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-ii/reviews/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-ii-review-6378024/|title=Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode II Review|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|date=May 22, 2012|accessdate=August 26, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620091604/http://uk.gamespot.com/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-ii/reviews/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-ii-review-6378024/|archivedate=June 20, 2012|df=mdy-all}} | GRadar = {{Rating|2.5|5}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/sonic-hedgehog-4-episode-ii-review/ |title=Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode II review 2012|accessdate=December 11, 2012}} | Joystiq = {{Rating|3|5}}{{cite web|last=Mitchell |first=Richard |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2012/05/16/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-2-review/ |title=Sonic the |url=http://www.oxm.co.uk/41628/reviews/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-2-review/ |title=Xbox Live Arcade Review: Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode 2 Review |publisher=Oxm.co.uk |date=May 17, 2012|accessdate=May 22, 2012}} | rev1 = ''[[Digital Spy]]'' | rev1Score = {{Rating|2|5}}{{cite web |url= http://www.digitalspy.com/gaming/review/a382850/sonic-4-episode-2-review-xbox-live-running-on-fumes.html |title='Sonic 4: Episode 2' review (Xbox Live): Running on fumes |last=Nichols|first=Scott|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|date=May 22, 2012|accessdate=June 29, 2012}} | rev2 = ''[[TouchArcade]]'' | rev2Score = (iOS) {{rating|4|5}}{{cite web |url=https://toucharcade.com/2012/05/16/sonic-the-hedgehog-4-episode-ii-review-another-new-sonic-game-that-isnt-terrible/ |title='Sonic the Hedgehog 4 Episode II' Review – Another New Sonic Game That Isn't Terrible |last=Nelson |first=Jared |date=May 16, 2012 |website=[[TouchArcade]] |accessdate=October 29, 2018}} }} ''Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode II'' received mixed reviews. [[Review aggregator]] website [[Metacritic]] gave the PlayStation 3 version 63/100, the Xbox 360 version 61/100, the PC version 54/100, and the iOS version 66/100. ''[[IGN]]''{{'s}} Lucas M. Thomas gave the game a score of 6.5, stating that while it fixes the physics problems of ''Episode I'', it is still missing the "magic" of its Genesis predecessors. ''[[GamesRadar+]]''{{'s}} Lucas Sullivan criticized it in similar ways, stating that the two-player mode "seems to prioritize griefing your friends instead making real in-game progress," and further stating that "every time we felt like we were reliving our old Sonic glory days, the next stage would incorporate limp and uninspired gimmicks like shifting winds or avalanche snowboarding." ''[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]''{{'s}} Ray Carsillo gave the game a 6.5, praising the "old-school Sonic" aspects of the gameplay, but criticizing the Tails-related gameplay, stating "there were too many puzzles that required Tails' assistance." ''[[Joystiq]]''{{'s}} Richard Mitchell had mixed feelings on the game as well, awarding it 3 out of 5 stars, and stating "''Episode 2'' makes improvements over its predecessor, with better visuals, useful co-op maneuvers and great special stages, but the inconsistent boss battles and uninspired level design keep it from recapturing Sonic's glory days." [[GameTrailers]] gave the game a score of 5.5, saying that the level design and the team-up moves often slow the pace of the game. ''[[Official Xbox Magazine]]''{{'s}} (UK) Jon Blyth was more positive, concluding that the game was "a smooth, slippery Sonic that takes another step away from it's {{sic}} single-button origins without losing any of the hog essence. With local and online co-op, it offers just enough entertainment to justify its steep episodic price." {{clear}} ==Notes== {{reflist|group=lower-alpha}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20141230153223/http://www.sega.co.uk/SONIC-THE-HEDGEHOG-4-Episode-II.aspx?r=true Official website] {{Sonic}} {{Sonic Team}} {{Portalbar|Sega|Sonic|Video games|2010s}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sonic the Hedgehog 4: Episode II}} [[Category:2012 video games]] [[Category:Android (operating system) games]] [[Category:Cancelled Wii games]] [[Category:Dimps games]] [[Category:Episodic video games]] [[Category:IOS games]] [[Category:Platform games]] [[Category:PlayStation Network games]] [[Category:PlayStation 3 games]] [[Category:Sonic the Hedgehog video games]] [[Category:Sega video games]] [[Category:Side-scrolling video games]] [[Category:Sonic Team games]] [[Category:Video game sequels]] [[Category:Video game prequels]] [[Category:Video games with 2.5D graphics]] [[Category:Cancelled Windows Phone games]] [[Category:Xbox 360 Live Arcade games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Ouya games]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] [[Category:Video games scored by Jun Senoue]]

{{italic title}} [[File:Suffrajitsu - Mrs. Pankhurst's Amazons cover.jpg|thumb|right|The cover of ''Suffrajitsu'', Issue #1.]]
'''''Suffrajitsu: Mrs. Pankhurst's Amazons''''' is a [[graphic novel]] trilogy published by Jet City Comics, portraying the adventures of an all-women secret society of [[bodyguards]] who protect the leaders of the radical [[suffragette]] movement during early 1914.<ref>[http://www.kindlepost.com/2015/01/guest-post-by-tony-wolf-author-of-suffrajitsu-mrs-pankhursts-amazons.html Kindle Post US: Guest Post by Tony Wolf Author of Suffrajitsu: Mrs. Pankhurst’s Amazons<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Publication history==
''Suffrajitsu'' was written by Tony Wolf, with art by Joao Vieira, colors by Josan Gonzales and lettering by Ed Dukeshire. Artwork, colors and lettering were supervised by Jasmine Amiri and Dafna Pleban of [[BOOM! Studios]]. Issue #1 was published on January 28, 2015, with Issues #2 and #3 being released on February 25 and March 25.<ref name=autogenerated1>http://www.suffrajitsu.com</ref>
Initial publication was as a series of [[e-books]] via the [[Amazon Kindle]] app, with individual issues also becoming available to both US and international readers via [[comiXology|comiXology.com]]. As of May 2015, collected editions became available via both the Kindle Fire and comiXology.
The ''Suffrajitsu'' trilogy is part of the [[Foreworld Saga]], a shared-world [[secret history]] transmedia franchise initiated by [[speculative fiction]] authors [[Neal Stephenson]] and [[Mark Teppo]] via the Subutai Corporation in 2010.<ref>http://www.foreworld.com</ref>
A printed collector's anthology edition, also including two other Foreworld graphic novels, ''The Dead God'' and ''Symposium'', was published as ''Blood and Honor: The Foreworld Saga Graphic Novels'' on July 29, 2015.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
==Premise and historical basis==
The majority of characters featured in the ''Suffrajitsu'' trilogy are fictionalized versions of real people and many events and locations shown are also closely based on real history.
The trilogy is set during the height of the English [[women's suffrage]] protests of the early 20th century, which included acts of mass [[civil disobedience]], [[sabotage]], and even [[riots]] as pro- and anti-suffragists battled over the right of women to vote in national elections. During this period, many suffragettes were imprisoned on charges ranging from [[vandalism]] and [[assault]] to [[sedition]].
In response to the so-called [[Cat and Mouse Act]] legislation, which allowed hunger-striking incarcerated suffragettes to be temporarily released from prison and then re-arrested when their health had sufficiently recovered, the [[Women's Social and Political Union]] established an [[Edith Margaret Garrud#Trainer of bodyguards|all-women bodyguard team]]. Trained by [[Edith Margaret Garrud]], the team - known within the WSPU as "The Bodyguard" and dubbed "jujitsuffragettes" and "Amazons" by the media - frequently clashed with the police, employing [[decoy]] and [[Military deception|subterfuge]] tactics as well as [[hand-to-hand combat]] to protect fugitive suffragettes from arrest and assault.<ref>[http://womenshistorynetwork.org/blog/?p=2928 Suffrajitsu – The Jiu Jitsu Teacher of the Woman’s War « Women's History Network Blog<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://observationdeck.io9.com/the-amazons-of-edwardian-london-kick-ass-suffragette-b-644342073?rev=1422999500817 Suffrajitsu: The Amazons of Edwardian London<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The Suffrajitsu trilogy also refers to numerous circa 1914 events, institutions and social movements notably including [[eugenics]], [[Bohemianism]], composer Alexander Scriabin's [[Mysterium (Scriabin)|Mysterium]] and the controversial [[White feather|White Feather]] campaign, which protagonist Persephone Wright rejects on ethical grounds.
==Issues==
Issue #1 of the trilogy follows Amazon leader Persephone Wright and her team as they engage in escalating conflicts with the police in London and Glasgow during early 1914. Most of the key events depicted in Issue #1 are closely based on real history, including sections of speeches by the politician [[William Cremer]] and both Emmeline and Christabel Pankhurst.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
In Issues 2 and 3 the plot dramatically diverges from real history, although major elements and characters are inspired by history. In Issue #2 the Amazons embark on a daring rescue mission in the Austrian Alps, battling with members of a [[eugenic]] cult called the Order of New Templars and in Issue 3 they must race to prevent a terrorist attack that may have dire consequences for the entire world.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
==Characters==
* '''Persephone Wright''': a "[[fallen woman]]", expert strategist and the field leader of the Amazons; partially inspired by real suffragettes including [[Gertrude Harding|Gert Harding]] and [[Elizabeth Robins]]. * '''[[Emmeline Pankhurst]]''': the leader of the radical [[Women's Social and Political Union]], and a fugitive from the law when the story begins. * '''[[Christabel Pankhurst]]''': Emmeline's daughter, and effectively the second-in-command of the WSPU. * '''[[Edward William Barton-Wright]]''': Persephone's uncle; owner of the [[Bartitsu]] Club (the Amazons' gymnasium/base of operations) and a staunch supporter of their activism. * '''[[Florence LeMar|Florence "Flossie" Le Mar]]''': a New Zealand-born adventuress. * '''[[Toupie Lowther]]''': an aristocratic, cross-dressing lesbian motorist, fencer and jujitsu exponent who serves as Mrs. Pankhurst's getaway driver and chauffeuse. * '''Judith Lee''': an amateur detective and expert lip-reader of Anglo-Chinese descent (adapted from the early 20th century "lady detective" character created by author [[Richard Marsh (author)|Richard Marsh]]). * '''[[Katie Sandwina|Katharina "Sandwina" Brumbach]]''': an Austrian professional wrestler and circus [[strongwoman]]. * '''Miss Sanderson''': a silent [[femme fatale]] who is an expert at self-defense with umbrellas and parasols. * '''Kitty Marshall''': a quick-witted teenager who keeps her suffragette activism secret from her family. * [[Vernon Kell|'''Vernon Waldegrave Kell''']]: the Director-General of the newly formed [[British Security Service]]. * '''[[Edith Margaret Garrud]]''' (cameo appearance): the Amazons' jiujitsu instructor and leader of the Palladium Irregulars, a reserve unit of suffragette bodyguards.
==Novellas and short stories==
During 2014 Suffrajitsu author Tony Wolf organised a scheme that produced two novellas and two short stories inspired by the Suffrajitsu trilogy and licensed and published via the [[Kindle Worlds]] platform. The stories included:
''The Pale Blue Ribbon'', by John Longenbaugh
''The Isle of Dogs'', by Michael Lussier
''Carried Away'', by Ray Dean
''The Second-Story Girl'', by Mark Lingane
With the closure of the Kindle Worlds platform in July of 2018, these short stories and novellas are no longer available.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Dy_Iu63ALY ''The Jujitsu Suffragette''] (BBC mini-documentary) * [http://thepandorasociety.com/suffrajitsu/ ''Suffrajitsu!''] (Jan. 2, 2015) * [https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2012/jun/25/edith-garrud-suffragette-martial-arts Edith Garrud: A public vote for the suffragette who taught martial arts] (''The Guardian'', Jun. 25 2012) * [http://www.bartitsu.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/08/Jujitsuffragette-interview.wav Radio interview with the author] (BBC World Service) * [http://www.kindlepost.com/2015/01/guest-post-by-tony-wolf-author-of-suffrajitsu-mrs-pankhursts-amazons.html Inspired by a true story ... no, really] (Amazon Kindle Blog, Jan. 26 2015) * [https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-34425615 ''Suffrajitsu'': How the suffragettes fought back using martial arts] (BBC News article referencing the graphic novel) * [http://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/suffrajitsu The Suffragettes Who Learned Martial Arts to Fight For the Vote] (Article on the suffragette Amazons in history and fiction, with Tony Wolf interview)

A '''Sunday drive''' is an [[automobile]] trip, primarily in the [[United States]] and Australia, typically taken for pleasure or leisure on a [[Sunday]], usually in the afternoon. During the Sunday drive, there is typically no destination and no rush.<ref>{{cite news|first=Katie|last=Clements|publisher=Guardian Newspapers|date=3 October 2007|accessdate=5 June 2009|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2007/oct/04/abrilliantstartforteamgbr|title=A brilliant start for Team GBR}}</ref>
==Origin== The use of the automobile for the Sunday drive began in the 1920s and 1930s. The idea was that the automobile was not used for commuting or errands, but for pleasure. There would be no rush to reach any particular destination.<ref name="1930s">{{cite book| title=The 1930s| first1=William H.|last1=Young| first2=Nancy K.|last2=Young| edition=illustrated| year=2002| page=234| isbn=978-0-313-31602-9}}</ref> The practice became increasingly popular throughout the 20th century. [[Parkway]]s were constructed for recreational driving of this sort{{Citation needed|date=May 2015}}.
==Views== Traveling on Sunday by automobile is questioned by some [[Christian]]s, due to observing [[Sunday Sabbath]]. While these parties consider the activity "leisure", they do not count it as "rest".<ref name="Holy Day, Holiday1">{{Cite book|title=Holy Day, Holiday|last=McCrossen|first=Alexis|year=2002|isbn=978-0-8014-8787-3|pages=79–80}}</ref> Stricter Sabbatarians consider leisure activities to be [[Sabbath breaking]], because excluded from the three permitted categories of works of piety, mercy, and necessity.<ref>{{bibleverse||Mark|2:23-27}}.</ref> Less strict Sabbath-keepers consider leisure to be "calling [[Sabbath in Christianity|Sabbath]] a delight".<ref>{{bibleverse||Isaiah|58:13}}.</ref> This reflects Jewish tradition, in which delighting in the day, spending freely on food, and traveling leisurely (i.e., more aimlessly and unhurriedly, and for shorter distances than one would during the week) were widely considered appropriate for ''[[Shabbat]]''.<ref>[[Tractate Shabbat]] 119a.</ref> In many Jewish traditions, [[Driving on Shabbat in Jewish law|driving on Shabbat]] is prohibited or severely restricted.
[[Henry Ford]] was an advocate of the Sunday drive. He promoted Sunday as a day of activity rather than rest because it led to the sale of automobiles.<ref name="day apart1">{{cite book|title=A Day Apart|last=Ringwald|year=2007|page=150|isbn=0-19-516536-5}}</ref>
==Effect of fuel prices== During the mid-[[2000s (decade)|2000s]], as a result of higher [[gas prices|gasoline prices]], some have curtailed their Sunday drives.<ref name="gas prices">{{cite news|title=Gas Prices Force Some to Change Their Lifestyles|date=August 20, 2005|author=Kyle Kennedy|publisher=The Ledger|page=A13|accessdate=5 June 2009| url=http://www.theledger.com/article/20050820/NEWS/508200352}}</ref> But after OPEC started increasing supply to hold market share against North American shale oil producers, oil and gasoline prices dropped to records levels leading some to go driving on Sunday again in the mid-2010s.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.drivingonsunday.com|title=Driving On Sunday|website=Driving On Sunday|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-30}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Staycation]]

page.title: The Blueprint 2: The Gift & The Curse

revision.text:
{{Infobox album | name = The Blueprint 2: The Gift & the Curse | type = studio | artist = [[Jay-Z]] | cover = jay-z-blueprint-2-gift-curse.jpg | border = yes | alt = | released = November 12, 2002 | recorded = December 2001 - September 2002 | venue = | studio = Baseline Studios
Manhattan Center Studios
[[New York, New York]] | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | length = 112:02 | label = {{hlist|[[Roc-A-Fella Records|Roc-A-Fella]]|[[Def Jam Recordings|Def Jam]]}} | producer = {{hlist|[[Jay-Z|Shawn Carter]] (exec.)|[[Damon Dash]] (exec.)|Kareem "Biggs" Burke (exec.)|Big Chuck|Charlemagne|Digga|[[Dr. Dre]]|[[Ron Feemster]]|[[Heavy D]]|[[Just Blaze]]|Jimi Kendrix|[[The Neptunes]]|[[No I.D.]]|[[Timbaland]]|[[Kanye West]]}} | prev_title = [[The Best of Both Worlds (Jay-Z and R. Kelly album)|The Best of Both Worlds]] | prev_year = 2002 | next_title = [[Blueprint 2.1]] | next_year = 2003 | misc = {{Singles | name = The Blueprint2: The Gift & The Curse | type = studio | single1 = [['03 Bonnie & Clyde]] | single1date = October 10, 2002 | single2 = [[Hovi Baby]] | single2date = November 12, 2002 | single3 = [[Excuse Me Miss]] | single3date = February 4, 2003 }} }} '''''The Blueprint 2: The Gift & the Curse''''' (stylized as '''''The Blueprint²: The Gift & the Curse''''') is the seventh [[studio album]] by American [[rapper]] [[Jay-Z]]. It was released on November 12, 2002, by [[Roc-A-Fella Records]] and [[Def Jam Recordings]]. The album serves as a sequel to his sixth album ''[[The Blueprint]]'' (2001). Parts of the album were later reissued for his compilation album, titled ''[[Blueprint 2.1]]'' (2003). The album debuted at number one, shipping with first-week sales of 545,000 units. As of February 2012, the album has sold 2,117,000 units in the United States.{{cite web|last=Grein |first=Paul |url=http://music.yahoo.com/blogs/chart-watch/week-ending-feb-26-2012-albums-half-top-160050213.html |title=Week Ending Feb. 26, 2012. Albums: Half of the Top 10 | Chart Watch (NEW) - Yahoo! Music |publisher=Music.yahoo.com |date=2012-02-29 |accessdate=2013-06-27}} == Background == {{unreferenced-section|date=September 2016}} The recording sessions took place after Jay-Z's critically acclaimed and commercially successful sixth album ''[[The Blueprint]]'' (2001), at the age of 32. The production on the album was handled primarily by [[Just Blaze]] and [[Kanye West]] - both of whom had recently established themselves as both of one of hip-hop's most celebrated producers due to the success of ''The Blueprint'' - while other producers include [[The Neptunes]], [[Timbaland]], [[No I.D.]], Darrell "Digga" Branch, Charlemagne, Big Chuck, [[Dr. Dre]], Jimmy Kendrick, [[Heavy D]], and Neff-U. Unlike ''The Blueprint'' which was almost void of guest appearances, ''The Blueprint²'' features many featured guests, even out-of-genre artists that include [[Lenny Kravitz]] and [[Sean Paul]]. Other features include West Coast rapper and producer Dr. Dre, [[Rakim]], [[Beyoncé]], [[Faith Evans]], [[Beanie Sigel]] and [[Scarface (rapper)|Scarface]]. The album also includes an uncredited verse from [[Kanye West]] on the Timbaland-produced track "The Bounce". Pharrell also provides vocals and hooks of many of his produced tracks, for example "[[Excuse Me Miss]]" and "Nigga Please". Though the album has no strict concept, the album contains two discs. The first disc entitled "The Gift" features mainstream, pop-oriented music. The second disc entitled "The Curse" contains dark, emotional, and bravado street songs such as the dark-toned retelling of "Meet the Parents", the emotional substance of escaping the dangerous ghetto in "Some How Some Way", the [[Nas]]-diss "Blueprint2", and the bravado "Nigga Please". == Critical reception == {{Album ratings |MC = 64/100 |rev1 = [[AllMusic]] |rev1score = {{rating|3|5}}{{AllMusic|class=album|id=r616634|pure_url=no}} |rev2 = ''[[Blender (magazine)|Blender]]'' |rev2Score = {{Rating|4|5}}{{cite magazine|magazine=[[Blender (magazine)|Blender]]|title=Review|page=156|date=December 2002}} |rev3 = ''[[Christgau's Consumer Guide]]'' |rev3Score = {{Rating-Christgau|hm1}}{{cite web|last=Christgau|first=Robert|authorlink=Robert Christgau|url=http://www.robertchristgau.com/get_album.php?id=11825|title=Consumer Guide Album: Jay-Z: The Blueprint 2|publisher=Robert Christgau|accessdate=September 7, 2016}} |rev4 = ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' |rev4score = C{{cite web|last1=Browne |first1=David |authorlink1=David Browne (journalist) |last2=Drumming |first2=Neil |last3=Serpick |first3=Evan |date=November 19, 2002 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080125100244/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0%2C%2C390697%2C00.html |archivedate=January 25, 2008 |title=H.O.V.A. Kill |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,390697,00.html |accessdate=September 7, 2016 |deadurl=yes }} |rev5 = ''[[NME]]'' |rev5score = 8/10{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/reviews/jay-z/6858 |title=NME Album Reviews – Jay-Z : The Blueprint 2 : The Gift & The Curse |publisher=Nme.Com |date=2005-09-12 |accessdate=2013-06-27}} |rev6 = ''[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]'' |rev6score = 7.5/10[http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/record_review/18837-the-blueprint-2-the-gift-and-the-curse-blueprint-21 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080429194604/http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/record_review/18837-the-blueprint-2-the-gift-and-the-curse-blueprint-21 |date=April 29, 2008 }} |rev7 = ''[[Q (magazine)|Q]]'' |rev7Score = {{Rating|4|5}}{{cite magazine|magazine=[[Q (magazine)|Q]]|title=Review|page=120|date=January 2003}} |rev8 = ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' |rev8score = {{rating|3|5}} |rev9 = ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]'' |rev9score = 9/10{{cite web|last=Ryan |first=Chris |url=http://www.spin.com/reviews/jay-z-blueprint-2-gift-and-curse-roc-fella |title=Jay-Z, 'The Blueprint 2: The Gift and the Curse' (Roc-a-Fella) | SPIN | Albums | Critical Mass |publisher=SPIN |date=2003-06-24 |accessdate=2013-06-27}} |rev10 = ''[[Uncut (magazine)|Uncut]]'' |rev10Score = {{Rating|2|5}}{{cite magazine|magazine=[[Uncut (magazine)|Uncut]]|title=Review|date=January 2003|page=119}} }} ''The Blueprint 2'' received lukewarm reviews from critics.{{cite web|last=Muhammad|first=Cedric|date=November 15, 2002|url=http://www.blackelectorate.com/articles.asp?ID=743|title=Hip-Hop Fridays: In Defense Of Jay-Z And Blueprint 2|work=Black Electorate|accessdate=September 7, 2016}} At [[Metacritic]], which assigns a [[standard score|normalized]] rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream publications, the album received an [[weighted mean|average]] score of 64, based on 19 reviews.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/the-blueprint-2-the-gift-the-curse/jay-z |title=Jay-Z Reviews |publisher=Metacritic |date= |accessdate=2002-11-12}} According to [[Nathan Rabin]], the record "led many to claim that [Jay-Z] lost his vise-like grip on rap music". In his review for ''[[The A.V. Club]]'', Rabin deemed it "overreaching but surprisingly solid", featuring a first disc of clever [[pop-rap]] jams and a second that was "darker and more erratic".{{cite web |last=Rabin |first=Nathan |url=http://origin.avclub.com/articles/jayz,12217/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120713063347/http://origin.avclub.com/articles/jayz,12217/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-13 |title=The Blueprint 2: The Gift & The Curse: Jay-Z | Music | MusicalWork Review | The A.V. Club |publisher=Origin.avclub.com |date=2002-12-06 |accessdate=2013-06-27 }} ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' critic Christian Hoard said ''The Blueprint 2'' was another "strong record from hip-hop's most dependable voice" but felt Jay-Z's [[flow (music)|flow]] was more impressive than the production, finding it "long on both bouncy funk and forgettable R&B samples".{{cite web|last=Hoard|first=Christian|date=November 12, 2002|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/the-blueprint-vol-2-the-gift-and-the-curse-20021112|title=The Blueprint, Vol. 2: The Gift and the Curse|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|accessdate=September 7, 2016}} [[AllMusic]]'s John Bush believed Jay-Z showcased some exceptional songs but could not carry the 110-minute double album as consistently as its predecessor.{{AllMusic|class=album|id=r616634|pure_url=no}} [[Soren Baker]] was more critical in the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''. He felt Jay-Z's reworking of other rappers' music ("It Was All a Dream", "'03 Bonnie & Clyde", and "The Watcher 2") was unimaginative while the rest of the album lacked his usual enthusiasm.{{cite web|last=Baker|first=Soren|authorlink=Soren Baker|date=November 24, 2002|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2002-11-24/news/0211240287_1_jay-z-def-jam-blueprint|title=The Blueprint 2 -- The Gift & The Curse|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|accessdate=September 7, 2016}} "It reminds me of nearly every other double CD", [[David Browne (journalist)|David Browne]] wrote in ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''. "It could have been a good single disc." [[Robert Christgau]] named "U Don't Know (Remix)" and "Poppin' Tags" as highlights while writing in his ''[[Village Voice]]'' consumer guide that he was disappointed Jay-Z sampled [[Paul Anka]] for "I Did It My Way" when he could not get permission to use [[Frank Sinatra]]'s recording of "[[My Way]]".{{cite news|last=Christgau|first=Robert|date=February 11, 2003|url=http://www.robertchristgau.com/xg/cg/cgv203-03.php|title=Consumer Guide: The Prelude|newspaper=[[The Village Voice]]|accessdate=September 7, 2016}} [[Cadence Weapon|Rollie Pemberton]] was more enthusiastic in his review for ''[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]'', writing that Jay-Z "weaves his way through every imaginable style and flavor with unyielding expertise". ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' hailed it as "the most ambitious and most fully realized album of his career",{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/73372/the-blueprint-2-the-gift-the-curse|title=The Blueprint 2: The Gift & the Curse|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=November 30, 2003|accessdate=September 7, 2016}} while ''[[Q (magazine)|Q]]'' felt it surpassed his previous album. In the opinion of ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]'' critic Chris Ryan, ''The Blueprint 2'' found Jay-Z "tightening the screws of his delivery" and discovering a "bruising poetry in a flow that once seemed clumsily conversational". == Track listing == {{Track listing | collapsed = | headline = Disc one: ''The Gift'' | extra_column = Producer(s) | title1 = A Dream | length1 = 4:12 | note1 = featuring The '''Clown's Prayer''' is a poem or prayer that comedians of various sorts use for inspiration. There have been several poems that have gone by that name. ==Author unknown== The original author of this poem is unknown. There are several variations on this poem. [[Chris Farley]] (from [[Saturday Night Live]] and [[Tommy Boy (film)|Tommy Boy]]) was known to have carried this prayer with him in his wallet.{{cite book|last1=Farley|first1=Tom|last2=Colby|first2=Tanner|title=The Chris Farley Show: A Biography in Three Acts|date=2008|publisher=Penguin|isbn=9780670019236|page=40|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hod_yMJ4840C&printsec=frontcover&dq=the+chris+farley+show&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjJ-LvL1KnKAhXEVD4KHRJbCa0Q6AEIKjAA#v=onepage&q=The%20Clown's%20Prayer&f=false|accessdate=14 January 2016}}{{cite book|last1=Gilpatrick|first1=Kristin|title=Famous Wisconsin Film Stars|date=2002|publisher=Badger Books Inc.|isbn=9781878569868|page=266|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kKPcSwYtbQUC&pg=PA266&dq=The+Clown%27s+Prayer&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwip1eeR0KnKAhUMdD4KHbH8Bq4Q6AEIJjAA#v=onepage&q=The%20Clown's%20Prayer&f=false|accessdate=14 January 2016}} It commonly includes the following four verses:{{cite book|last1=Eneli|first1=Aya|title=Live Your Abundant Life|date=2004|publisher=Xulon Press|isbn=9781594676611|page=211|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pxlGJ0TWrTUC&pg=PA211&dq=The+Clown%27s+Prayer&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwip1eeR0KnKAhUMdD4KHbH8Bq4Q6AEIQDAF#v=onepage&q=The%20Clown's%20Prayer&f=false|accessdate=14 January 2016}}
As I stumble through this life, help me to create more laughter than tears, dispense more happiness than gloom, spread more cheer than despair. Never let me become so indifferent, that I will fail to see the wonders in the eyes of a child, or the twinkle in the eyes of the aged. Never let me forget that my total effort is to cheer people, make them happy, and forget momentarily, all the unpleasantness in their lives. And in my final moment, may I hear You whisper: "When you made My people smile, you made Me smile."
Occasionally the following verse is inserted between the third and fourth verses above:{{cite book|last1=Clowns of America International|title=20 Years of Laughter|date=2006|publisher=Turner Publishing Company|isbn=9781596520738|page=6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D-F-HfP8YR8C&pg=PA109&dq=The+Clown%27s+Prayer&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwip1eeR0KnKAhUMdD4KHbH8Bq4Q6AEIMjAC#v=onepage&q=The%20Clown's%20Prayer&f=false|accessdate=14 January 2016}}
Never let me acquire success to the point that I discontinue calling on my Creator in the hour of need, Acknowledging and thanking Him in the hour of plenty.
==Clowns International== [[Clowns International]] hosts a service every year on the first Sunday in February at [[Holy Trinity Church, Dalston#The Clowns' Church|The Clowns' Church]] in London, and they recite a version of the Clown's Prayer then.{{cite book|last1=Bain|first1=Roly|last2=Forbes|first2=Patrick|title=Clowning Glory|date=1995|publisher=Church House Publishing|isbn=9780715148631|page=99|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y307g259-YUC&pg=PA98&dq=The+Clown%27s+Prayer&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjnuPzl-KnKAhUFOT4KHT-bC64Q6AEIVjAJ#v=onepage&q=The%20Clown's%20Prayer&f=false|accessdate=14 January 2016}} ==Walter Grogan== This version was written by [[Walter Grogan]] and published in ''[[The Pall Mall Magazine]]'' in 1907.{{cite news|last1=Grogan|first1=Walter|title=The Clown's Prayer|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=At5LAQAAMAAJ&pg=PR5&dq=The+Clown%27s+Prayer&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwip1eeR0KnKAhUMdD4KHbH8Bq4Q6AEIRTAG#v=onepage&q=The%20Clown's%20Prayer&f=false|accessdate=14 January 2016|work=The Pall Mall Magazine|issue=39|publisher=George Routledge & Sons|date=1907}}
Lord, I am poor, I have no gift Meet for Thy shrine; My life is spent in joke and jest, So empty, vain, e'en at its best, This life of mine. But, Lord, beneath my mirthful face I hide a tear, And when the crowd laugh at the fair They seem to gibe at my despair And mock my fear. Lord, I am poor save in this wise: A child have I, And as I joke the best I may, He, uncomplaining fades away And soon must die. Lord, thou hast many in thy home, I only one; Think, Lord, a jester's life is sad, Change not "he has" into "he had," -- Grant me my son.
==See also== *[[Christian comedy]] *[[Genesius of Rome]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Clown's Prayer, The}} [[Category:Clowning]] [[Category:Prayer]] [[Category:Poems]] {{Christianity-stub}} {{comedy-stub}}

revision.text:
{{infobox Organization |name = Österreichischer Versuchssenderverband
Austrian Amateur Radio Society |image = OEVSV_logo.png |image_border = |size = 100px |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = ÖVSV, OEVSV |motto = |formation = 1921 |extinction = |type = [[Non-profit organization]] |status = |purpose = Advocacy, Education |headquarters = |location = [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] |region_served = [[Austria]] |membership = |language = [[Austrian German]] |leader_title = President |leader_name = Michael Zwingl OE3MZC |main_organ = |affiliations = [[International Amateur Radio Union]] |num_staff = |budget = |website = http://www.oevsv.at/ |remarks = }} The '''Österreichischer Versuchssenderverband''' ('''OEVSV''') (in [[English language|English]], '''Austrian Amateur Radio Society''') is a national [[non-profit organization]] for [[amateur radio]] enthusiasts in [[Austria]]. Key membership benefits of the OEVSV include the sponsorship of [[amateur radio operating award]]s, radio [[contesting|contests]], and a [[QSL card|QSL]] bureau for members who regularly communicate with [[amateur radio operator]]s in other countries. OEVSV represents the interests of Austrian amateur radio operators before Austrian and international telecommunications regulatory authorities. The OEVSV is organized on a federal model, with a ''Dachverband'', the National Umbrella Organisation, nine ''Landesverbände'', the Provincial Associations, and the [[Austrian Military Radio Society]].Österreichischer Versuchssenderverband (2008). [http://www.oevsv.at/opencms/EN/oevsv/ "Österreichischer Versuchssenderverband (ÖVSV) - Austrian Amateur Radio Society"]. Retrieved Aug. 12, 2008. OEVSV is the national member society representing Austria in the [[International Amateur Radio Union]].International Amateur Radio Union (2008). [http://www.iaru.org/iaru-soc.html "Member Societies"]. Retrieved Aug. 1, 2008. == Radiosport == OEVSV organizes annually two amateur radio contests:[http://www.oevsv.at/opencms/funkbetrieb/contest-hf.html ÖVSV HF-Contest] * The All-OE 40/80m contest and cross-service event, always on May 1 * The All-OE 160m contest in November == See also == *[[International Amateur Radio Union]] == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Osterreichischer Versuchssenderverband}} [[Category:International Amateur Radio Union member societies|Austria]] [[Category:Non-profit organisations based in Austria]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1921]] [[Category:1921 establishments in Austria]] [[Category:Organisations based in Vienna]] [[Category:Radio in Austria]] {{Austria-org-stub}} {{Amateur-radio-stub}}
